arm_group.description: High protein intake: large bolus of protein in teh diet the day before testing
No protein in the diet the day before testing

brief_summary.textblock:
In the present study, the effect of habitual dietary protein on the anabolic response will
      be investigated.

clinical_study.brief_title: Manipulation of Dietary Protein and the Anabolic Response
condition: Focus: Anabolic Response to Food Intake in Young Individuals.
Condition Relevance: Skeletal Muscle Health, Sarcopenia.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Males

          -  Aged between 18-35 years

          -  Healthy, recreationally active

          -  BMI < 30 kg/m2

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Smoking

          -  Allergies to milk proteins (whey or casein)

          -  Vegetarians

          -  Diagnosed GI tract diseases

          -  Female

          -  Arthritic conditions

          -  A history of neuromuscular problems

          -  Previous participation in amino acid tracer studies

          -  Individuals on any medications known to affect protein metabolism (i.e.
             corticosteroids, non-steroidal anti-inflammatories, or prescription strength acne
             medications

clinical_study.official_title: The Manipulation of Dietary Protein Intake on the Anabolic Response in Healthy Young Men

oversight_info.authority: Netherlands: The Central Committee on Research Involving Human Subjects (CCMO)

primary_outcome.description: The ability of the muscle to synthesise new proteins will be assessed over a 3 h period following protein ingestion and will be compared between groups. This only occurs on one occasion.
primary_outcome.measure: Muscle protein fractional synthetic rate following protein ingestion

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Basic Science
